{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3367827,"name":"Sam Geckler","username":"sgeckler","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sgeckler/{size}/66162_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-21T12:56:59.357Z","cooked":"

Team 4926 has completed an analysis of a failure we observed at the Indiana District Championship. We are posting this failure analysis to show the community a real example of one FRC failure mechanism we all face. Although I find it embarrassing this happened at our District Championship, hopefully the sequence of issues we identified here can help others avoid similar problems down the road. The process that we used to identify the failure, in collaboration with event staff and mentors from other teams, was methodical even in the heat of the competition. It makes me sad an otherwise very capable robot had this problem and couldn’t play to its potential, but as always FRC is a fertile ground for learning! There are a few additional pictures I plan to add, but unfortunately GalacTech’s work space hasn’t had power since April 2nd .

TL/DR- Failure summary - But check out the document for pictures!

  1. Positive Side battery terminal insulation damaged and makes contact with the aluminum battery mount - FAIL POINT #1.
  2. Aluminum battery mount connected to the frame, so the frame is at 12V potential now also.
  3. The aluminum housing of the Ethernet switch rubs on a bolt head removes the exterior coating allowing 12V to the housing of the ethernet switch - FAIL POINT #2.
  4. The housing of the ethernet switch is internally grounded to the barrel connector power wire.
  5. The barrel connector returns through the VRM negative to the PDH negative
  6. The PDH negative returns to battery negative
  7. The battery is shorted through the small gauge ethernet switch power wire.
  8. There are no fuses or breakers in this path.

That’s a nice analysis.

I note that the exposed metal on the battery terminal should have been found in inspection (R607). The damaged heat shrink might have been missed, but not the exposed bolt. Do you recall whether the RI looked at all of your batteries? Did any of your other batteries also have exposed metal?

I do not believe each battery was inspected, but I can’t really remember. However the cut heat shrink very likely emerged during the competition. The exposed bolt was probably there from the beginning.
